SubTopics: Distinguish their own point of view from that of the narrator or those of the characters.
Content: Based on paragraphs 8 and 9 of Passage 1, with which statement would Yolanda 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗟𝗜𝗞𝗘𝗟𝗬 agree?

A.Choice: Neighbors should keep their windows closed when playing loud music.

B.Choice: Roosters can be welcome members of the neighborhood.

C.Choice: Abuelo enjoys it when neighbors copy his movements.

D.Choice: Mami's bread is the freshest in the neighborhood.

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Make connections between the text of a story or drama and a visual or oral presentation of the text, identifying where each version reflects specific descriptions and directions in the text.
Content: How does the picture in Passage 1 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 help the reader better understand the passage?

A.Choice: It shows the heat of the day.

B.Choice: It shows the steps for playing dominoes.

C.Choice: It shows the closeness between Yolanda and Abuelo.

D.Choice: It shows the thoughts and feelings of Abuelo's friends.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 27 in Passage 1.
:box:Mr. Perera sits back down, g͟r͟u͟m͟b͟l͟i͟n͟g͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟ ͟a͟ ͟s͟u͟m͟m͟e͟r͟ ͟t͟h͟u͟n͟d͟e͟r͟s͟t͟o͟r͟m.
As used in the sentence, what does the phrase g͟r͟u͟m͟b͟l͟i͟n͟g͟ ͟l͟i͟k͟e͟ ͟a͟ ͟s͟u͟m͟m͟e͟r͟ ͟t͟h͟u͟n͟d͟e͟r͟s͟t͟o͟r͟m show about Mr. Perera?

C.Choice: He is interested in others.

D.Choice: He is comfortable with change.

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Make connections between the text of a story or drama and a visual or oral presentation of the text, identifying where each version reflects specific descriptions and directions in the text.
Content: What important detail about Passage 2 does the picture 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 help the reader understand?

A.Choice: The country air is fresh and clean.

B.Choice: The milk truck is large and speedy.

C.Choice: Grandpa and the narrator have fun together.

D.Choice: Grandpa enjoys driving more than anything.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: According to Passage 2, what happens to milk when it goes into the tanks?

C.Choice: It smells better.

D.Choice: It changes color.

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Which word 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 describes the narrator in Passage 2?

C.Choice: hungry

D.Choice: bored

Content: Which detail from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to the question above?

A.Choice: “I rub the sleep out of my eyes.”

B.Choice: “In a few minutes we pull into a long driveway.”

C.Choice: “I wonder if the cows are sleepy or if they like getting up this early.”

D.Choice: “Snack in hand, we're back on the road, headed for town.”

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast the treatment of similar themes and topics (e.g., opposition of good and evil) and patterns of events (e.g., the quest) in stories, myths, and traditional literature from different cultures.
Content: How are the settings of Passage 1 and Passage 2 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 different?

A.Choice: Passage 1 takes place in winter. Passage 2 takes place in fall.

B.Choice: Passage 1 takes place in the city. Passage 2 takes place in the country.

C.Choice: Passage 1 takes place in the past. Passage 2 takes place in the future.

D.Choice: Passage 1 takes place in Cuba. Passage 2 takes place in the United States.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 1.
:ibox:Daniel looked out his bedroom window, gazing down onto the field and i͟t͟c͟h͟i͟n͟g to join his friends.
What does the word i͟t͟c͟h͟i͟n͟g mean as it is used in the sentence?

C.Choice: quickly scratching

D.Choice: suddenly running

SubTopics: Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
Content: Based on the passage, which word 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 describes Daniel's friends?

C.Choice: helpful

D.Choice: confused

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: In the passage, why do Daniel and his friends eat the berries? Select 𝗧𝗪𝗢 answers.

A.Choice: because they are hungry and thirsty

B.Choice: because they want berries with ice cream

C.Choice: because the berries are too sweet and juicy to resist

D.Choice: because they have filled the bucket and it is overflowing

E.Choice: because they think they should make sure the berries are fresh

SubTopics: Distinguish their own point of view from that of the narrator or those of the characters.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 9.
:box:What a great day it had been!
In the sentence, whose point of view is 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡𝗟𝗬 shown?

C.Choice: the reader's

D.Choice: the author's

SubTopics: Refer to parts of stories, dramas, and poems when writing or speaking about a text, using terms such as chapter, scene, and stanza; describe how each successive part builds on earlier sections.
Content: How do the berry stains on Daniel become important later in the story?

A.Choice: They show that Daniel is more forgetful than his brother.

B.Choice: They show that Daniel has disappointed his dad.

C.Choice: They show Daniel's dad what has happened.

D.Choice: They show Daniel's friends why he is tired.

SubTopics: Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Based on the passage, what is a 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡 lesson Dad helps Daniel learn?

A.Choice: Things may not go as planned, but they can still work out well.

B.Choice: Eating healthy meals each day will help you grow strong.

C.Choice: It is important for everyone in a family to help out.

D.Choice: Finish your work first, and then you can play.

Content: Which detail from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer above?

A.Choice: “He could join them just as soon as he finished cleaning his room.”

B.Choice: “'Hot dogs and corn on the cob!' Daniel shouted.”

C.Choice: “His father went grocery shopping.”

D.Choice: “'Daniel,' he said, 'this is the perfect amount.'”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 3 topic or subject area.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 7 in Passage 1.
:box:Somewhere, a family of river otters is snuggled together in their c͟o͟z͟y underground den, while far away on a dark sea, a baby otter sleeps on its mother under a starry sky.
As it is used in the sentence, what does c͟o͟z͟y 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗡𝗘𝗔𝗥𝗟𝗬 mean?

C.Choice: crowded

D.Choice: comfortable

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the logical connection between particular sentences and paragraphs in a text (e.g., comparison, cause/effect, first/second/third in a sequence).
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
What is the 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡 way the author connects the information about sea otters and river otters in Passage 1?

A.Choice: The author lists problems the otters have and the solutions to those problems.

B.Choice: The author describes the causes of pollution and its effects on otters.

C.Choice: The author tells how the otters are alike and how they are different.

D.Choice: The author gives the order of the activities in the otters' day.

Content: Which detail from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer above?

A.Choice: “You could watch them play forever, but you know there are lots of other creatures to see.”

B.Choice: “No otters are playing at this exhibit. Here it is nap time.”

C.Choice: “The baby looks so content on its furry floating bed.”

D.Choice: “Later that night, you read the booklet and fall asleep.”

SubTopics: Distinguish their own point of view from that of the author of a text.
Content: With which idea would the author of Passage 1 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗟𝗜𝗞𝗘𝗟𝗬 agree?

B.Choice: Spending the day at the zoo is boring.

C.Choice: Otters and humans are alike in many ways.

D.Choice: Other creatures at the zoo are more exciting than otters.

SubTopics: Ask and answer questions to demonstrate understanding of a text, referring explicitly to the text as the basis for the answers.
Content: According to Passage 2, why do the first signs of water pollution appear in otters?

C.Choice: because they are playful animals

D.Choice: because their homes are in water

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Based on Passage 2, how does oil spilled from broken pipes 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡𝗟𝗬 cause danger to otters?

C.Choice: by heating up the air they breathe

D.Choice: by making the land and water dirty

SubTopics: Use text features and search tools (e.g., key words, sidebars, hyperlinks) to locate information relevant to a given topic efficiently.
Content: Which part of Passage 2 describes where sea otters sleep?

C.Choice: Hᴇʟᴘ Is ᴏɴ ᴛʜᴇ Wᴀʏ!

D.Choice: Hᴇʟᴘ Is Hᴇʀᴇ ᴛᴏ Sᴛᴀʏ!

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: Based on details from 𝗕𝗢𝗧𝗛 passages, why does blue-green algae affect more sea otters than river otters?

A.Choice: Only sea otters swim in water with this algae.

B.Choice: Only sea otters eat clams that may contain this algae.

C.Choice: Only sea otters can roam on land where the algae grows.

D.Choice: Only sea otters sleep in kelp beds that may contain crabs.

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: Where should the writer move sentence 5 to show the correct order of events in the story?

C.Choice: before sentence 3

D.Choice: before sentence 4

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: Read this sentence.
:ibox:𝟔. One day after school, Bernie neared the bakery and noticed many colorful cupcakes.
Which set of words in sentence 6 helps to show the order of events in the story?

C.Choice: the bakery

D.Choice: noticed many

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Read this sentence.
:box:𝟏𝟎. She had helped him with his work after school, and Bernie had been thinking about a good way to thank her.
How does sentence 10 help the reader understand the events of the story?

A.Choice: by explaining why Bernie enjoys sweets

B.Choice: by explaining why Bernie walks by the bakery

C.Choice: by explaining why Bernie wants to give his teacher a present

D.Choice: by explaining why Bernie likes looking at the treats in the window

Content: Which sentence from the story 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 shows that the answer above is correct?

A.Choice: “Mr. Costello would proudly display his freshly baked goods there for everyone to see.”

B.Choice: “He was drawing a group of flowers in pink icing around the base of the cake.”

C.Choice: “Bernie watched as Mr. Costello made animal faces on the sweet treats using candies and icing.”

D.Choice: “With Mr. Costello's help, Bernie made a perfect cupcake for Mrs. Torres.”

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: Read this sentence.
:box:𝟏𝟓. “͟I͟ ͟w͟a͟n͟t͟ ͟t͟o͟ ͟m͟a͟k͟e͟ ͟m͟y͟ ͟t͟e͟a͟c͟h͟e͟r͟ ͟a͟ ͟c͟u͟p͟c͟a͟k͟e͟ ͟f͟o͟r͟ ͟a͟ ͟p͟r͟e͟s͟e͟n͟t͟ ͟B͟e͟r͟n͟i͟e͟ ͟a͟n͟s͟w͟e͟r͟e͟d͟ ͟e͟a͟g͟e͟r͟l͟y͟.
What is the correct way to write sentence 15?

A.Choice: “I want to make my teacher a cupcake for a present. Bernie answered eagerly.”

B.Choice: “I want to make my teacher a cupcake for a present, Bernie answered eagerly.”

C.Choice: “I want to make my teacher a cupcake for a present,” Bernie answered eagerly.

D.Choice: “I want to make my teacher a cupcake for a present Bernie answered eagerly.”

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Content: Read this sentence.
:box:𝟏𝟕. Mr. Costello s͟m͟i͟l͟e͟s at Bernie.
What is the correct way to write the underlined word in sentence 17?

C.Choice: smiled

D.Choice: will smile

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: Read this sentence.
:box:𝟐𝟑. He could not wait to give her the yellow cupcake with blue frosting and white jelly bean c͟l͟o͟w͟d͟s.
How should the underlined word in sentence 23 be written?

C.Choice: cloudes

D.Choice: clouds

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: At the beginning of the passage, the writer wants to help the reader imagine the topic. Which sentence would be 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 to add after sentence 2?

A.Choice: You may have seen people skateboarding in parks or in skateboarding contests.

B.Choice: You know a garage is a place to put skateboards and bicycles.

C.Choice: People go from place to place during the day.

D.Choice: There are many kinds of things with wheels.

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: Read this sentence.
:box:𝟑. About 100 years ago, people used skateboards, a͟n͟d͟ ͟s͟o they were very different from the ones people use now.
How should the underlined words in sentence 3 be changed to 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 bring the writer's ideas together?

C.Choice: later

D.Choice: unless

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning word and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read these sentences.
:box:𝟗. They were slippery like ice and u͟n͟s͟t͟e͟a͟d͟y. 𝟏𝟎. They did not grip well to sidewalks and other places people skated.
What does the word unsteady mean as it is used in sentence 9?

C.Choice: leaky

D.Choice: shaky

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: Read this sentence.
:box:People could stop, turn, and move more easily on them.
Where should this sentence be placed in the passage to 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 show how skateboards have changed?

C.Choice: after sentence 10

D.Choice: after sentence 12

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: Read this sentence.
:box:𝟏𝟓. People thought up new tricks t͟o͟ ͟s͟h͟o͟w͟ ͟o͟f͟f͟ ͟o͟n͟ ͟s͟k͟a͟t͟e͟b͟o͟a͟r͟d͟s.
How should the underlined part of sentence 15 be changed to 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 explain how skateboarding became popular?

A.Choice: that made them better at skateboarding.

B.Choice: that brought more changes to skateboarding.

C.Choice: that made skateboarding more exciting to watch.

D.Choice: that proved skateboarding had become simple to do.

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Read this sentence.
:box:𝟐𝟎. F͟o͟r͟ ͟t͟h͟i͟n͟g͟s͟ ͟t͟o͟ ͟w͟e͟a͟r, they should always wear helmets, knee pads, and gloves.
How should the underlined part of sentence 20 be changed to 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 join the writer's ideas in the last paragraph?

C.Choice: On older skateboards

D.Choice: For extra power on skateboards

Content: Which words from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 support the correct answer above?

C.Choice: “towns and cities have built special parks”

D.Choice: “but people can still fall”

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: Now read the writing task and draft a response. As you write, think about what makes your writing the best it can be.
problems/NMG3E/media/33a.jpg

:box:You have read a story about students reading a school newsletter. You have also read a page from that newsletter. The newsletter lists many exciting school events. Pick one of these events or another event that might happen at a school. Write a story to share with your class. Tell about a real or imaginary time when you or someone else went to a school event. Use ideas from what you have read, along with your own ideas, to write your story.

:ibox:Today you will be writing a narrative. When you write a narrative, you

• tell about real or imaginary events.
• think about the characters you want to introduce.
• put events in an order that makes sense.
• use details and dialogue to make the events and characters interesting.
• think about how your story can affect the feelings of your reader.

After you have read the passages, and before you begin writing, think about

• who your narrative will be about.
• what events you want your narrative to include.
• when and where the events in your narrative happen.
• why the people in your narrative think and act as they do.

Now write your response in the space provided.
